questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except:
questions.solution:
Boundaries of the Calot’s triangle is not formed by the gall bladder.

Calot's triangle is formed by 3C's:

  • Medially – Common hepatic duct
  • Inferiorly – Cystic duct
  • Superior – Cystic artery 

This is the most common site of injury in laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Related Pearl: Calot's triangle and hepatobiliary triangle

Boundaries Calot's Triangle Hepatobiliary Triangle

Superiorly

 Superior border of the Cystic artery Inferior surface of the Liver

Medially

 Common Hepatic Duct

Inferiorly

 Cystic duct

Importance: 

Contents of Calot’s triangle:

  • The cystic artery—artery supplying the gallbladder
  • Lymph node of Lund—sentinel lymph node for the gallbladder

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have
questions.solution:
After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

Mnemonic - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with hyperuricemia and delayed developmental milestones. He also has the habit of biting his lips, fingers, and feet because of which he is always strapped to the bed. Urine examined showed orange sands. Which is the most probable enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It is caused due to the complete deficiency of Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine, from which excessive amounts of uric acid is produced and excreted in urine as orange sands.

Clinical features include compulsive self-mutilation, hyperuricemia, intellectual disability, delayed milestones, dystonic movements and megaloblastic anemia.

Diagnosis is made by deficient HGPRTase enzyme activity in the erythrocyte. Partial deficiency of HGPRTase cause Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Option 1) Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase enzyme deficiency causes urinary calculus formation with crystalluria.

Option 3) Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the  2nd major cause of SCID.

Option 4) Purine nucleoside phosphorylase causes a severe deficiency of T cells but B cells are normal.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV seropositive male presents with raised violaceous plaques over the distal portion of the lower limbs. Biopsy shows a lesion composed of proliferating spindle cells along with small vessels and spaces containing red cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are most suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma.

Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is highly associated with AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome).

Classic Kaposi sarcoma occurs in older men of Eastern European and Meditteranean descent and has the following three clinical stages:

  • Patches- red-purple macules on the distal lower extremities
  • Plaques- patches progress to large violaceous raised plaques. Lesions spread proximally.
  • Nodules- Lesions become nodular with more neoplastic features. This stage also progresses to involve nodes and viscera.

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells:

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with fever and chills for the last 3 days. A peripheral blood smear revealed the following. Which of the following is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the peripheral smear showing the Maurer's dots are suggestive of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

Features of Plasmodium falciparum on peripheral smear are Maurer’s dots, ring form, accole form, and banana-shaped gametocytes.

Related Pearl: Difference between plasmodium species

Feature P.vivax P.ovale P.falciparum P.malaria
Discovered by Grassi & Feletti Stephens Welch Laveran
Erythrocyte preference Reticulocytes Reticulocytes All stages Old erythrocytes
Stages found in peripheral blood Trophozoite, schizonts, gametocytes As in vivax Ring form, accole form, gametocytes Band forms
Infected erythrocyte Enlarged pale with Schuffner’s dots Pear-shaped, fimbriated, Jame’s dots Normal size, Maurer’s cleft Normal size, Ziemann’s stippling
Gametocyte Spherical, fills the cell Similar to but smaller than vivax Crescent, Banana shaped Similar to but smaller than vivax
Color of pigment Yellowish-brown Yellowish-brown Black Dark brown
Hypnozoites Present Present Absent Absent
Relapse Yes Yes No No
Average IP(days) 14 14 12 (shortest) 30 (longest)
Duration of erythrocyte cycle(hours) 48 (Benign tertian) 48 (ovale tertian) 48 (malignant tertian) 72(Quartan malaria)
Others       Nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: Apparent volume of distribution of a drug is very high (6L/kg). Which of the following is true regarding the distribution of that drug?
questions.solution:
If the volume of distribution exceeds total body fluid volume, then the drug has distribution in extravascular tissues.

In the present case, the volume of distribution of the drug is 6L/kg (420 L in a normal adult with reference weight 70kg) that is very high when compared to the normal blood volume of 5 liters. Therefore, it can be implied that the drug is having high sequestration in tissues.

The apparent volume of distribution (Vd) = dose administered I.V/ plasma concentration

A high aVd is due to the accumulation of a drug in extravascular tissues resulting in low plasma concentration. 

A high plasma protein binding usually results in the low volume of distribution which approximates around blood volume. (Option A)

questions.text: While doing the hydrostatic test, an unrespired lung may float due to:
questions.solution:
An unrespired lung (still birth) may float due to gases of decomposition, as seen in putrefaction.

Hydrostatic test is done to determine whether the newborn has respired or not. It is also known as Floatation test/ Breslau’s first life test/ Raygat’s test.

If the lung pieces float in water, it means that respiration has taken place, indicating a live birth.

If the pieces sink, respiration has not taken place, which means it is a stillborn.

A respired lung (live birth) may sink in water in the following conditions :

  • Lung edema
  • Lung collapse
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a foetus after respiration.

Principle : Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Foetus is macerated or mummified.
  • Foetus is born before 180 days of gestation.
  • Stomach contains milk.
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed.

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Image shown above is Perichondritis.

  • MC cause is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non iatrogenic (laceration, haematoma). It can be due to extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of meatus.
  • MC organism – Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Pinna is red, hot, painful and stiff.

Cauliflower ear: also known as perichondrial hematoma or wrestler's ear, is a deformity of the ear caused by trauma.

Chondrodermatitis chronica helicis : small, nodular, tender, chronic inflammatory lesion occurring on the helix of the ear.

Otitis externa : also called swimmer's ear, is inflammation of the ear canal.

questions.text: The cherry red spot seen in the image below is seen in _______.
questions.solution:
The image shows a cherry-red spot, which is a feature of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

Pathophysiology of the cherry-red spot:

A cherry-red spot of the macula is typical and arises in this area because of the absence of ganglion cells at the foveola resulting in the transmission of the normal choroidal color. This in contrast to the surrounding area where intense retinal whitening blocks the transmission of the normal choroidal color.

Risk factors of CRAO:

  • Heart disease
  • Carotid artery disease
  • Mucormycosis
  • Trauma

Clinical features of CRAO:

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Severe edema: The whole retina looks white in color.
  • Marked attenuation of arteries: thread-like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in the artery and veins: cattle-track appearance
  • Cherry-red spot
  • Hollenhorst plaques - cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles.

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the intraocular pressure (IOP) by intravenous mannitol or ocular massage. The time limit is only 4 to 6 hours.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: Which of the following gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size?
questions.solution:
Total fertility rate gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It represents the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women in each age group now.
  • It is the sum of all age specific fertility rates multiplied by 5.
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size.

questions.text: Endoscopes are sterilized by ______
questions.solution:
• 2% glutaraldehyde is commonly used to disinfect and sterilize endoscopes, which includes fibreoptic scopes.
  • Another aldehyde used in disinfection is formaldehyde.
  • Aldehydes in 2% solutions achieve sporicidal activities.

Related Pearl: Methods of Sterilization and Disinfection

  Spectrum Uses/comments
Heat    
Autoclaving All  
Boiling Most pathogens, some spores  
Pasteurization Vegetative bacteria Beverages, plastic hospital equipment
Ethylene oxide gas All Potentially explosive, aeration required
Radiation    
UV All poor penetration
Ionising All general, food
Chemicals    
Alcohol Vegetative bacteria, viruses some spores  
Hydrogen peroxide Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi contact lens, inactivated by organic material
chlorine Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi water, inactivated by organic matter 
Iodophors  Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi  skin disinfection, inactivated by organic matter
Phenol  Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi hand washing
Glutaraldehyde   All  endoscopes 
Quarternary ammonium compounds Most bacteria, fungi, lipophilic viruses  general cleaning, inactivated by organic matter

questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
Disaster Management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: 

  Involves immediate management of mass casualties

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery:

   Involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fatigue, chronic diarrhea,  steatorrhea, weight loss, bone pain, and abdominal distension.  Investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia and osteoporosis. Which of the following is the single best test to be done for her evaluation?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of celiac disease, and the single best investigation to diagnose the condition is IgA tissue trans-glutaminase antibodies.

Celiac disease is a disorder characterized by an immunological response to gluten causing damage to the proximal intestinal mucosa, and malabsorption of nutrients. 

The typical symptoms include weight loss, chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, abdominal distension, and growth retardation. The malabsorption of nutrients may cause the following conditions:

  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Bruising due to vitamin K deficiency
  • Bone pain due to osteomalacia
  • Hyperkeratosis due to vitamin A deficiency
  • Neurological signs like peripheral neuropathy and ataxia due to vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.text: A 43-year-old obese man presents with loud chronic snoring and gasping episodes during sleep along with excessive daytime sleepiness. He is diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea. Which of the following would be the ideal therapy for his symptoms?

choices.text: Implantable neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS). The ideal therapy is continuous positive airway pressure therapy (CPAP).

Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is the most common surgery done in OSAHS but it is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.

Supplemental oxygenation can improve oxygen saturation but there is little evidence that it improves OSAHS symptoms.

Unilateral neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve through a surgically implanted device is a recently tested therapy for OSAHS. It can be used as an alternative in selected patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.

questions.text: A worker from the cement industry got a chest X-ray as a part of his routine health check-up. What could cause the findings in the given chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis could cause the findings in the given chest X-ray.

The given X-ray shows irregular opacities, which appear to be pleural thickenings i.e., pleural plaques. The sign along with a history of working in the cement industry suggests a diagnosis of asbestosis. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes. 

Workers of the cement, shipping, and textile industries are at a higher risk of developing asbestosis. Asbestos tends to involve the pleura first. The earliest manifestation is benign asbestosis related pleural effusion. With time, the plaques are calcified resulting in the formation of thick pleural plaques. The pleural thickenings can be seen on the X-ray. This is the “holly leaf sign”.

Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years). They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

Related Pearl: Occupational Lung Diseases

Occupational lung diseases

Occupation / Cause

Asbestosis

Shipping, textile, cement and roofing sheet manufacturing industries

Silicosis

Mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, glass manufacturing, quarrying industries

Bagassosis

Sugarcane fibers

Byssinosis (brown lung disease/ Monday fever) 

Cotton, flax, hemp, and jute fiber

Farmer’s lung

Thermophilic actinomycetes 

Bird Fancier’s lung

 Hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by bird droppings   
Chalicosis (flint disease)  In stonecutters, due to inhalation of fine particles of stone

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with a history of fever and cough since 3 days and hemoptysis since 1 day. She has no other comorbid illnesses. On examination, pulse rate is 96 bpm, BP is 118/70 mmHg, temperature is 100.4 degree F, RR is 15/min and SpO2 is 96%. CT scan shows localised ground-glass opacity in the left posterior lobe of the lung. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given patient is suffering from COVID-19.

Hemoptysis is one of the atypical manifestations of COVID-19. It may be present with more common features such as fever and cough. CT-finding of localized ground-glass opacity is also supportive of the diagnosis.

Other atypical manifestations of COVID-19 include:

  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Cardiac: Myocardial infarction, myocarditis, pericarditis, and pericardial effusion
  • Neurological: Stroke, Guillain‐Barre Syndrome, viral encephalitis, toxic encephalopathy, acute hemorrhagic necrotizing encephalopathy, olfactory and taste disorders
  • Gastrointestinal: Diarrhea, nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain
  • Ocular: conjunctivitis, epiphora
  • Cutaneous: erythematous rash, widespread urticaria, chickenpox‐like vesicles, localized pruritic lesions, and petechial skin rash

questions.text: Mrs. Latha presents to the clinic at 12 weeks of gestational age with a history of a lump in her right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, you find a lump of 2 X 1 cm in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. Which of the following investigations would you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present with a breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and is able to detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes.

USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 40 years) since breast tissue is dense in these populations.

Other options:

Option A- Mammography is less useful in pregnant women due to the increased density of breast tissue.

Option C- MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in cases where metastasis or spread to other breast is suspected.

Option D- Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC)  is not recommended in pregnant women. It is difficult to distinguish breast cancer from the normal cellular proliferation in the breast tissue due to hormonal changes.

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in Frey’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
The Auriculotemporal nerve (V3 nerve) is involved in Frey's syndrome.

Frey’s syndrome/Gustatory sweating (auriculotemporal syndrome) commonly develops after parotid surgery or other surgery or trauma that results in the opening of the parotid capsule.

It is thought to reflect abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face by regrowing parasympathetic secretomotor axons that would previously have innervated the parotid gland.

It is characterized by sweating, warmth, and redness of the face as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.

 

Management:

Denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion has been advocated but is often not curative. The symptoms can be managed by the subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area and the use of antiperspirant.

questions.text: The given image shows a congenital bronchopulmonary malformation. Which of the following commonly supplies the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The given CT shows an intralobar pulmonary sequestration of the left lung. Thoracic aorta commonly supplies the sequestered lobe of the lung.

  • Pulmonary Sequestration is an area of Embryonic Lung Tissue, separate from the lung, which receives blood supply from an anomalous systemic artery from the Aorta.
  • Extralobar Sequestration occurs primarily on the left side and blood supply is usually from the Thoracic or upper Abdominal Aorta.
  • Intralobar Sequestration occurs in the lower lobes predominantly (>95%) and is equally distributed between the right and left lower lobe and blood supply is from the descending Thoracic aorta, venous drainage via pulmonary veins.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of tracheo-esophageal fistula?
questions.solution:
Image C shows the commonest variety of Tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF).

TEF is an abnormal communication between Esophagus and Trachea. With each breath, the air enters the distal esophagus and the stomach causing gastric distention which presents as abdominal distention. 

Type C is the most common - it has proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF (the proximal blind pouch ends at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF).

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies. The inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube is a crucial pointer in the diagnosis of esophageal atresia. 

 

 

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheoesophageal Fistula

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: If used early reduces cardiac output
Delayed clamping should be avoided in Rh- pregnancy
It is to be removed 48 hours after birth
Increases iron stores in the baby

questions.solution:
The given image shows an umbilical cord clamp. It should be kept in place until it falls off with the detached stump of the umbilical cord.

It is made of plastic and supplied in a sterile pack. It occludes the umbilical vessels effectively. In preterm infants, delayed clamping may improve transitional circulation, establish better red blood cell volume, reduce the need for blood transfusion and reduce the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis and intraventricular haemorrhage. It should be delayed by 30-60 seconds after birth.

Other options:

Option A: If performed early reduces cardiac output owing to reduced preload to the left ventricle whereas if performed late permits sufficient aeration of the lung and improved / smoother transitioning to a better cardiac output.

Option B: Early cord clamping is advised in Rh-negative pregnancy, babies with asphyxia, or infants of diabetic mothers. Early clamping can also reduce the need for phototherapy due to hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option D: Delayed umbilical cord clamping in term infants will increase haemoglobin levels at birth and improve iron stores for the first few months. This may have a favourable effect on developmental outcomes.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics?
questions.solution:
Placental abruption is the most common cause of severe consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics.

Consumptive coagulopathy, also known as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), is a pathologic disruption of hemostasis. It is characterized by systemic activation of blood coagulation, which results in thrombosis and fibrin deposition in the small blood vessels throughout the body.

Other causes of DIC in pregnancy:

  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Sepsis
  • Preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome
  • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy
  • Postpartum haemorrhage.

questions.text: Identify the type of ovarian tumor in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows cut specimen of ovary with hair and sebum – Dermoid cyst which is a germ cell tumor.

Dermoid cyst

  • A benign teratoma
  • Most common benign tumor of ovary in reproductive age group
  • Most common benign tumor of ovary diagnosed in pregnancy
  • Most common germ cell tumor (overall)
  • It is the commonest tumor to undergo torsion.
  • It is bilateral in 10-15% cases.
  • Rokitansky’s protuberance, which is a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands along with teeth & bones can be seen.
  • Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological study – known as Struma Ovarii.
  • Most common tissue elements found are ectodermal derivatives.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of mental retardation, failure to walk or talk, failure to grow, seizures, hyperactivity, and tremors. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU).

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)
  • Mousey/musty odor is characteristically seen in phenylketonuria.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: Identify the following correctly.

choices.text: A - Simple bone cyst, B - Aneurysmal bone cyst, C - Giant cell tumor (GCT)
A - Aneurysmal bone cyst, B - GCT, C - Simple bone cyst
A - GCT, B - Aneurysmal bone cyst, C - Simple bone cyst
A - GCT, B - Simple bone cyst, C - Aneurysmal bone cyst

questions.solution:
Giant cell tumor (GCT):

Appears on a mature skeleton. Well circumscribed, expansile, sub-articular, eccentric, lytic lesion. The lesion has characteristic soap-bubble appearance with minimal marginal sclerosis. Epiphyseal location.

Aneurysmal bone cyst:

Appears on an immature skeleton (we can see that the epiphysis is not fused). Highly expansile and eccentrically located, lytic lesion. Highly trabeculated and lobulated. Metaphyseal location.

Simple bone cyst:

Appears on an immature skeleton. Most commonly affects proximal humerus. Centrally located, lytic lesion. Metaphyseal location

 

Related Pearl: Summary of Bone Tumors

Bone tumor Most common site Age
Simple bone cyst Proximal Humeral Metaphysis <20years
Enchondroma

Hand bones

(Metaphysis of small bones of hand)

4th & 5th

Decade

Osteochondroma

(Exostosis)

 Distal Femoral Metaphysis <18years
Osteoid osteoma Diaphysis of Femur

2nd & 3rd

decade
Osteoblastoma Posterior column of vertebra

2nd & 3rd

decade

Osteoclastoma (GCT)

 Distal femoral epiphysis

2nd -4th

Decade
Aneurysmal Bone Cyst Long bone Metaphysis <18years
Osteosarcoma Distal Femoral Metaphysis

BIMODAL

Primary- 2nd Decade Secondary-6th and 7th Decade
Ewings sarcoma Diaphysis of Femur 5-25 years
Chondrosarcoma Any site in the bone - mc in proximal femur 3rd-5th decade
Clear cell chondrosarcoma Proximal femoral epiphysis  3rd-5th decade
Adamantinoma Diaphysis of Tibia  20-40 years
 Fibrous dysplasia  The upper end of femur > tibia  1st to 3rd decade
 Chordoma  Sacrum  5th to 7th decade
Multiple myeloma Vertebrae 5th to 7th decade

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the X-ray given below.
questions.solution:
Achondroplasia is a congenital genetic disorder resulting in rhizomelic dwarfism (proximal limb shortening) and is the most common cause of disproportionate dwarfism.

The champagne glass pelvis is a sign in achondroplasia in which the iliac blades are flattened, giving rise to a pelvic inlet that resembles a champagne glass. The acetabular angles are flattened (horizontal) and the sacrosciatic notch is small.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has a fight with his neighbour. The next day he feels that his neighbours are following him and recording his movements and he fears that they are planning to kill him. What do his symptoms represent?
questions.solution:
Thoughts of being harmed, followed by people around him represent delusion of persecution. It is the most common type of delusion.

Delusion is a false, firm, fixed (unshakable) belief which is not in keeping with the patient’s socio-cultural and educational background.

Delusions are of two types based on their origin:

  • Primary: Arise de-novo and cannot be explained based on previous experiences, characteristic of schizophrenia.
  • Secondary: Delusions that are secondary to other morbid psychological conditions like depressive moods and hallucinations.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetics is to be avoided in a hypertensive patient?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is avoided in hypertensive patients as it has intrinsic sympathomimetic properties and hence can aggravate hypertension.

This is due to central stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system and inhibition of the reuptake of norepinephrine. And hence it should be cautiously used in patients with uncontrolled hypertension, coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure and arterial aneurysms.

Other intravenous induction agents like propofol and thiopentone produce a fall in blood pressure. Etomidate is an induction agent that does not alter the blood pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding piebaldism?

choices.text: Small spots of hyperpigmentation can also be seen

questions.solution:
White forelock is quite common in Piebaldism.

Piebaldism:

  • Autosomal dominant benign condition, it has mutations in c‐KIT.
  • Well-defined irregular hypopigmented macules with an absence of melnocytes.
  • Small spots of hyperpigmentation are also seen within hypopigmented patches or on normal skin. 
  • It is often associated with a V-shaped leucoderma on mid-forehead.
  • Both sexes are equally affected.
  • Piebaldism can be distinguished from vitiligo because of the neonatal presence of white patches.
  • Epidermal cell or skin grafting is the treatment.

questions.text: Contrast used in CT____
questions.solution:
Iodinated contrast is used in CT, IVP, and angiography. All these are based on X-rays and iodine is a radio-opaque substance.

In the contrast medium, Iodine provides the radiopacity; the other elements of the contrast medium molecule provide no radiopacity but act as carriers of the iodine, greatly increasing the solubility and markedly reducing the toxicity of the molecule.
